<h2 id="Key-Takeaways">Key Takeaways<a class="anchor-link" href="#Key-Takeaways">¶</a></h2><ul>
<li>The "sell in May and go away" myth has been alive and well for the past 25 years.  Average returns in "winter" months have been more than 2x returns in "summer" months</li>
<li>We also find strong weekly cycles, with Monday, Tuesday, and Wednesday producing more than 2x the rate of return (per day) as Thursday and Friday.   </li>
<li>The strongest - and most consistent - cycle is monthly.  Best days are the end/beginning of the month and the 11th through 18th. </li>
</ul>
</div>
</div>
</div>
<div class="cell border-box-sizing text_cell rendered"><div class="prompt input_prompt">
</div>
<div class="inner_cell">
<div class="text_cell_render border-box-sizing rendered_html">
<h2 id="Introduction">Introduction<a class="anchor-link" href="#Introduction">¶</a></h2><p>Most investors have heard the adage "Sell in May and go away" which reflects the common wisdom that markets perform less well during the summer months than during the winter.  This anomaly is well described <a href="https://www.investopedia.com/news/truth-about-sell-may-and-go-away/">here</a>.</p>
<p>Many widely held beliefs go away, precisely because they're widely held and get priced into the market.  I'd like to test the "sell in May" myth to see how well it has held up.  This is also a great case example to illustrate seasonality analysis - something which I believe gets too little attention because it seems "too simple" to work.</p>
<p>In this post, I'll walk through a simple approach to replicating this anomaly using only end-of-day price data and a bit of python code.  If you'd like to replicate and experiment with the below code, <em>you can download the source notebook for this post by right-clicking on the below button and choosing "save link as"</em></p>
<p><a href="https://github.com/convergenceIM/alpha-scientist/blob/master/content/Sell_in_May.ipynb" style="text-align: center;"><img src="images/button_ipynb-notebook.png" title="download ipynb"/></a></p>
<h2 id="Getting-Started">Getting Started<a class="anchor-link" href="#Getting-Started">¶</a></h2><p>We first need to load returns data.  You'll need to replace this code for your data source of choice, but make sure you use <em>adjusted</em> returns, since unadjusted returns will introduce all sorts of errors related to dividend dates, changes in yield, splits and so forth.</p>
<p>Also, I'm going to use log returns here since they're additive across time.  In other words, the sum of daily log returns is equal to the monthly log return, which is not (quite) true of simple returns.  Since we are mostly using daily returns, you can more or less think of the log returns as simple returns.</p>
<p>Our dataset goes back to the beginning of SPY in 1993</p>
</div>
</div>
</div>
<div class="cell border-box-sizing code_cell rendered">
<div class="input">
<div class="prompt input_prompt">In [1]:</div>
<div class="inner_cell">
<div class="input_area">
<div class=" highlight hl-ipython3"><pre><span></span><span class="kn">import</span> <span class="nn">numpy</span> <span class="k">as</span> <span class="nn">np</span>
<span class="kn">import</span> <span class="nn">pandas</span> <span class="k">as</span> <span class="nn">pd</span>

<span class="kn">import</span> <span class="nn">matplotlib.pyplot</span> <span class="k">as</span> <span class="nn">plt</span>
<span class="o">%</span><span class="k">matplotlib</span> inline
<span class="kn">from</span> <span class="nn">IPython</span> <span class="k">import</span> <span class="n">display</span>
<span class="kn">from</span> <span class="nn">IPython.core.display</span> <span class="k">import</span> <span class="n">Image</span>

<span class="c1">## The below imports interface to my (proprietary)</span>
<span class="c1">## price database.  Replace this code with your own</span>
<span class="c1">## source for downloading price data</span>

<span class="kn">import</span> <span class="nn">sys</span>
<span class="n">sys</span><span class="o">.</span><span class="n">path</span><span class="o">.</span><span class="n">append</span><span class="p">(</span><span class="s1">'/anaconda/'</span><span class="p">)</span>
<span class="kn">import</span> <span class="nn">config</span>
<span class="n">sys</span><span class="o">.</span><span class="n">path</span><span class="o">.</span><span class="n">append</span><span class="p">(</span><span class="n">config</span><span class="o">.</span><span class="n">REPO_ROOT</span><span class="o">+</span><span class="s1">'data/'</span><span class="p">)</span>
<span class="kn">from</span> <span class="nn">prices.eod</span> <span class="k">import</span> <span class="n">read</span>


<span class="c1">## Load Data</span>
<span class="n">symbols</span> <span class="o">=</span> <span class="p">[</span><span class="s1">'SPY'</span><span class="p">]</span>
<span class="n">prices</span> <span class="o">=</span> <span class="n">read</span><span class="o">.</span><span class="n">get_symbols_close</span><span class="p">(</span><span class="n">symbols</span><span class="p">,</span><span class="n">adjusted</span><span class="o">=</span><span class="kc">True</span><span class="p">)</span>
<span class="n">returns</span> <span class="o">=</span> <span class="n">prices</span><span class="o">.</span><span class="n">pct_change</span><span class="p">()</span>
<span class="n">log_ret</span> <span class="o">=</span> <span class="n">np</span><span class="o">.</span><span class="n">log</span><span class="p">(</span><span class="n">prices</span><span class="p">)</span><span class="o">.</span><span class="n">diff</span><span class="p">()</span>
<span class="n">spy</span> <span class="o">=</span> <span class="n">log_ret</span><span class="o">.</span><span class="n">SPY</span><span class="o">.</span><span class="n">dropna</span><span class="p">()</span>
<span class="nb">print</span><span class="p">(</span><span class="n">spy</span><span class="o">.</span><span class="n">head</span><span class="p">())</span>
</pre></div>
</div>
</div>
</div>
<div class="output_wrapper">
<div class="output">
<div class="output_area">
<div class="prompt"></div>
<div class="output_subarea output_stream output_stdout output_text">
<pre>date
1993-02-01    0.007087
1993-02-02    0.002116
1993-02-03    0.010515
1993-02-04    0.004175
1993-02-05   -0.000695
Name: SPY, dtype: float64
</pre>
</div>
</div>
</div>
</div>
</div>
<div class="cell border-box-sizing text_cell rendered"><div class="prompt input_prompt">
</div>
<div class="inner_cell">
<div class="text_cell_render border-box-sizing rendered_html">
<h3 id="Sell-in-May?">Sell in May?<a class="anchor-link" href="#Sell-in-May?">¶</a></h3><p>We'll start analyzing the data by calculating average log returns by calendar month.  Note that, since we're using div/split adjusted prices, these are <em>total</em> returns:</p>
</div>
</div>
</div>
<div class="cell border-box-sizing code_cell rendered">
<div class="input">
<div class="prompt input_prompt">In [2]:</div>
<div class="inner_cell">
<div class="input_area">
<div class=" highlight hl-ipython3"><pre><span></span><span class="n">df</span> <span class="o">=</span> <span class="n">spy</span><span class="o">.</span><span class="n">to_frame</span><span class="p">(</span><span class="n">name</span><span class="o">=</span><span class="s1">'pct_chg'</span><span class="p">)</span>
<span class="n">by_month</span> <span class="o">=</span> <span class="n">df</span><span class="o">.</span><span class="n">resample</span><span class="p">(</span><span class="s1">'BM'</span><span class="p">)</span><span class="o">.</span><span class="n">sum</span><span class="p">()</span>
<span class="n">by_month</span><span class="p">[</span><span class="s1">'month'</span><span class="p">]</span> <span class="o">=</span> <span class="n">by_month</span><span class="o">.</span><span class="n">index</span><span class="o">.</span><span class="n">month</span>

<span class="n">title</span><span class="o">=</span><span class="s1">'Avg Log Return (%): by Calendar Month (1993-present)'</span>
<span class="n">ax</span> <span class="o">=</span> <span class="p">(</span><span class="n">by_month</span><span class="o">.</span><span class="n">groupby</span><span class="p">(</span><span class="s1">'month'</span><span class="p">)</span><span class="o">.</span><span class="n">pct_chg</span><span class="o">.</span><span class="n">mean</span><span class="p">()</span><span class="o">*</span><span class="mi">100</span><span class="p">)</span><span class="o">.</span><span class="n">plot</span>\
<span class="o">.</span><span class="n">bar</span><span class="p">(</span><span class="n">color</span><span class="o">=</span><span class="s1">'grey'</span><span class="p">,</span><span class="n">title</span><span class="o">=</span><span class="n">title</span><span class="p">)</span>
<span class="n">ax</span><span class="o">.</span><span class="n">axhline</span><span class="p">(</span><span class="n">y</span><span class="o">=</span><span class="mf">0.00</span><span class="p">,</span> <span class="n">color</span><span class="o">=</span><span class="s1">'grey'</span><span class="p">,</span> <span class="n">linestyle</span><span class="o">=</span><span class="s1">'--'</span><span class="p">,</span> <span class="n">lw</span><span class="o">=</span><span class="mi">2</span><span class="p">)</span>
</pre></div>
</div>
</div>
</div>
<div class="output_wrapper">
<div class="output">
<div class="output_area">
<div class="prompt output_prompt">Out[2]:</div>
<div class="output_text output_subarea output_execute_result">

<div class="cell border-box-sizing text_cell rendered"><div class="prompt input_prompt">
</div>
<div class="inner_cell">
<div class="text_cell_render border-box-sizing rendered_html">
<p>Wow, maybe there's some truth to this myth!  It appears that there is a strong difference between the summer months (June to September) and the rest.</p>
<p>From the above chart, it appears than we'd be well advised to sell on June 1st and buy back on September 30th.  However, to follow the commonly used interpretation of selling on May 1st and repurchasing on Oct 31st.  I'll group the data into those two periods and calculate the monthly average:</p>
</div>
</div>
</div>
<div class="cell border-box-sizing code_cell rendered">
<div class="input">
<div class="prompt input_prompt">In [3]:</div>
<div class="inner_cell">
<div class="input_area">
<div class=" highlight hl-ipython3"><pre><span></span><span class="n">by_month</span><span class="p">[</span><span class="s1">'season'</span><span class="p">]</span> <span class="o">=</span> <span class="kc">None</span>
<span class="n">by_month</span><span class="o">.</span><span class="n">loc</span><span class="p">[</span><span class="n">by_month</span><span class="o">.</span><span class="n">month</span><span class="o">.</span><span class="n">between</span><span class="p">(</span><span class="mi">5</span><span class="p">,</span><span class="mi">10</span><span class="p">),</span><span class="s1">'season'</span><span class="p">]</span> <span class="o">=</span> <span class="s1">'may_oct'</span>
<span class="n">by_month</span><span class="o">.</span><span class="n">loc</span><span class="p">[</span><span class="o">~</span><span class="n">by_month</span><span class="o">.</span><span class="n">month</span><span class="o">.</span><span class="n">between</span><span class="p">(</span><span class="mi">5</span><span class="p">,</span><span class="mi">10</span><span class="p">),</span><span class="s1">'season'</span><span class="p">]</span> <span class="o">=</span> <span class="s1">'nov_apr'</span>

<span class="p">(</span><span class="n">by_month</span><span class="o">.</span><span class="n">groupby</span><span class="p">(</span><span class="s1">'season'</span><span class="p">)</span><span class="o">.</span><span class="n">pct_chg</span><span class="o">.</span><span class="n">mean</span><span class="p">()</span><span class="o">*</span><span class="mi">100</span><span class="p">)</span><span class="o">.</span><span class="n">plot</span><span class="o">.</span><span class="n">bar</span>\
<span class="p">(</span><span class="n">title</span><span class="o">=</span><span class="s1">'Avg Monthly Log Return (%): </span><span class="se">\n</span><span class="s1">May-Oct vs Nov_Apr (1993-present)'</span>\
 <span class="p">,</span><span class="n">color</span><span class="o">=</span><span class="s1">'grey'</span><span class="p">)</span>
</pre></div>
</div>
</div>
</div>

<div class="output">
<div class="output_area">
<div class="prompt output_prompt">Out[3]:</div>

<div class="cell border-box-sizing text_cell rendered"><div class="prompt input_prompt">
</div>
<div class="inner_cell">
<div class="text_cell_render border-box-sizing rendered_html">
<p>A significant difference.  The "winter" months are more than double the average return of the summer months.  But has this anomaly been taken out of the market by genius quants and vampire squid?  Let's look at this breakout by year:</p>
</div>
</div>
</div>
<div class="cell border-box-sizing code_cell rendered">
<div class="input">
<div class="prompt input_prompt">In [4]:</div>
<div class="inner_cell">
<div class="input_area">
<div class=" highlight hl-ipython3"><pre><span></span><span class="n">by_month</span><span class="p">[</span><span class="s1">'year'</span><span class="p">]</span> <span class="o">=</span> <span class="n">by_month</span><span class="o">.</span><span class="n">index</span><span class="o">.</span><span class="n">year</span>

<span class="n">title</span><span class="o">=</span><span class="s1">'Avg Monthly Log Return (%): </span><span class="se">\n</span><span class="s1">May-Oct vs Nov-Apr (1993-present)'</span>
<span class="n">ax</span> <span class="o">=</span> <span class="p">(</span><span class="n">by_month</span><span class="o">.</span><span class="n">groupby</span><span class="p">([</span><span class="s1">'year'</span><span class="p">,</span><span class="s1">'season'</span><span class="p">])</span><span class="o">.</span><span class="n">pct_chg</span><span class="o">.</span><span class="n">mean</span><span class="p">()</span><span class="o">.</span><span class="n">unstack</span><span class="p">()</span><span class="o">*</span><span class="mi">100</span><span class="p">)</span><span class="o">.</span><span class="n">plot</span><span class="p">(</span><span class="n">title</span><span class="o">=</span><span class="n">title</span><span class="p">)</span>
<span class="n">ax</span><span class="o">.</span><span class="n">axhline</span><span class="p">(</span><span class="n">y</span><span class="o">=</span><span class="mf">0.00</span><span class="p">,</span> <span class="n">color</span><span class="o">=</span><span class="s1">'grey'</span><span class="p">,</span> <span class="n">linestyle</span><span class="o">=</span><span class="s1">'--'</span><span class="p">,</span> <span class="n">lw</span><span class="o">=</span><span class="mi">2</span><span class="p">)</span>
</pre></div>
</div>
</div>
</div>

<div class="cell border-box-sizing text_cell rendered"><div class="prompt input_prompt">
</div>
<div class="inner_cell">
<div class="text_cell_render border-box-sizing rendered_html">
<p>It's a bit noisy, so let's make a four year rolling average):</p>
</div>
</div>
</div>
<div class="cell border-box-sizing code_cell rendered">
<div class="input">
<div class="prompt input_prompt">In [5]:</div>
<div class="inner_cell">
<div class="input_area">
<div class=" highlight hl-ipython3"><pre><span></span><span class="n">title</span><span class="o">=</span><span class="s1">'Avg Monthly Log Return (%) by Season</span><span class="se">\n</span><span class="s1">Four Year Moving Average (1993-present)'</span>
<span class="n">by_month</span><span class="p">[</span><span class="s1">'year'</span><span class="p">]</span> <span class="o">=</span> <span class="n">by_month</span><span class="o">.</span><span class="n">index</span><span class="o">.</span><span class="n">year</span>
<span class="n">ax</span> <span class="o">=</span> <span class="p">(</span><span class="n">by_month</span><span class="o">.</span><span class="n">groupby</span><span class="p">([</span><span class="s1">'year'</span><span class="p">,</span><span class="s1">'season'</span><span class="p">])</span><span class="o">.</span><span class="n">pct_chg</span><span class="o">.</span><span class="n">mean</span><span class="p">()</span><span class="o">.</span><span class="n">unstack</span><span class="p">()</span><span class="o">.</span><span class="n">rolling</span><span class="p">(</span><span class="mi">4</span><span class="p">)</span><span class="o">.</span><span class="n">mean</span><span class="p">()</span><span class="o">*</span><span class="mi">100</span><span class="p">)</span><span class="o">.</span><span class="n">plot</span><span class="p">(</span><span class="n">title</span><span class="o">=</span><span class="n">title</span><span class="p">)</span>
<span class="n">ax</span><span class="o">.</span><span class="n">axhline</span><span class="p">(</span><span class="n">y</span><span class="o">=</span><span class="mf">0.00</span><span class="p">,</span> <span class="n">color</span><span class="o">=</span><span class="s1">'grey'</span><span class="p">,</span> <span class="n">linestyle</span><span class="o">=</span><span class="s1">'--'</span><span class="p">,</span> <span class="n">lw</span><span class="o">=</span><span class="mi">2</span><span class="p">)</span>
</pre></div>
</div>
</div>
</div>

<div class="cell border-box-sizing text_cell rendered"><div class="prompt input_prompt">
</div>
<div class="inner_cell">
<div class="text_cell_render border-box-sizing rendered_html">
<p>It appears that the effect hasn't gone away at all!  If anything, it's had a resurgence in the past 10 years.</p>
<p>One theory I've seen floated is that this is predominantly driven by presidential elections - and the market uncertainty thereof.  To test that, I'll group data into election years and non-election years:</p>
</div>
</div>
</div>
<div class="cell border-box-sizing code_cell rendered">
<div class="input">
<div class="prompt input_prompt">In [6]:</div>
<div class="inner_cell">
<div class="input_area">
<div class=" highlight hl-ipython3"><pre><span></span><span class="n">election_years</span> <span class="o">=</span> <span class="p">[</span><span class="s1">'1996'</span><span class="p">,</span><span class="s1">'2000'</span><span class="p">,</span><span class="s1">'2004'</span><span class="p">,</span><span class="s1">'2008'</span><span class="p">,</span><span class="s1">'2012'</span><span class="p">,</span><span class="s1">'2016'</span><span class="p">]</span>
<span class="n">by_month</span><span class="p">[</span><span class="s1">'election_year'</span><span class="p">]</span> <span class="o">=</span> <span class="kc">False</span>
<span class="n">by_month</span><span class="o">.</span><span class="n">loc</span><span class="p">[</span><span class="n">by_month</span><span class="o">.</span><span class="n">year</span><span class="o">.</span><span class="n">isin</span><span class="p">(</span><span class="n">election_years</span><span class="p">),</span><span class="s1">'election_year'</span><span class="p">]</span> <span class="o">=</span> <span class="kc">True</span>

<span class="n">title</span> <span class="o">=</span> <span class="s1">'Average Monthly Returns (log) for Non-Election Years vs. Election Years'</span>
<span class="n">ax</span> <span class="o">=</span> <span class="p">(</span><span class="n">by_month</span><span class="o">.</span><span class="n">groupby</span><span class="p">([</span><span class="s1">'election_year'</span><span class="p">,</span><span class="s1">'season'</span><span class="p">])</span><span class="o">.</span><span class="n">pct_chg</span><span class="o">.</span><span class="n">mean</span><span class="p">()</span>\
      <span class="o">.</span><span class="n">unstack</span><span class="p">()</span><span class="o">*</span><span class="mi">100</span><span class="p">)</span><span class="o">.</span><span class="n">plot</span><span class="o">.</span><span class="n">bar</span><span class="p">(</span><span class="n">title</span><span class="o">=</span><span class="n">title</span><span class="p">)</span>
<span class="n">ax</span><span class="o">.</span><span class="n">axhline</span><span class="p">(</span><span class="n">y</span><span class="o">=</span><span class="mf">0.00</span><span class="p">,</span> <span class="n">color</span><span class="o">=</span><span class="s1">'grey'</span><span class="p">,</span> <span class="n">linestyle</span><span class="o">=</span><span class="s1">'--'</span><span class="p">,</span> <span class="n">lw</span><span class="o">=</span><span class="mi">2</span><span class="p">)</span>
</pre></div>
</div>
</div>
</div>

<div class="cell border-box-sizing text_cell rendered"><div class="prompt input_prompt">
</div>
<div class="inner_cell">
<div class="text_cell_render border-box-sizing rendered_html">
<p>Indeed, there does appear to be <em>more</em> truth to the axiom in election years, but it remains significantly valid in off years as well.  Mark Hulbert <a href="https://www.marketwatch.com/story/heres-the-real-story-behind-sell-in-may-and-go-away-2017-04-25">analyzed this theory</a> back to 1897 and sees similar results.</p>
<h3 id="Day-of-Week">Day of Week<a class="anchor-link" href="#Day-of-Week">¶</a></h3><p>Now that we've validated our first pattern, I'd like to test for other calendar patterns.  Let's first look at days of week, looking at the average return by day of week:</p>
</div>
</div>
</div>
<div class="cell border-box-sizing code_cell rendered">
<div class="input">
<div class="prompt input_prompt">In [7]:</div>
<div class="inner_cell">
<div class="input_area">
<div class=" highlight hl-ipython3"><pre><span></span><span class="n">df</span> <span class="o">=</span> <span class="n">spy</span><span class="o">.</span><span class="n">to_frame</span><span class="p">(</span><span class="n">name</span><span class="o">=</span><span class="s1">'pct_chg'</span><span class="p">)</span>
<span class="n">by_day</span> <span class="o">=</span> <span class="n">df</span>
<span class="n">by_day</span><span class="p">[</span><span class="s1">'day_of_week'</span><span class="p">]</span> <span class="o">=</span> <span class="n">by_day</span><span class="o">.</span><span class="n">index</span><span class="o">.</span><span class="n">weekday</span><span class="o">+</span> <span class="mi">1</span>

<span class="p">(</span><span class="n">by_day</span><span class="o">.</span><span class="n">groupby</span><span class="p">(</span><span class="s1">'day_of_week'</span><span class="p">)</span><span class="o">.</span><span class="n">pct_chg</span><span class="o">.</span><span class="n">mean</span><span class="p">()</span><span class="o">*</span><span class="mi">100</span><span class="p">)</span><span class="o">.</span><span class="n">plot</span><span class="o">.</span><span class="n">bar</span>\
<span class="p">(</span><span class="n">title</span><span class="o">=</span><span class="s1">'Avg Daily Log Return (%): by Day of Week (1993-present)'</span><span class="p">,</span><span class="n">color</span><span class="o">=</span><span class="s1">'grey'</span><span class="p">)</span>
</pre></div>
</div>
</div>
</div>
<div class="output_wrapper">
<div class="output">
<div class="output_area">
<div class="prompt output_prompt">Out[7]:</div>
<div class="output_text output_subarea output_execute_result">
<pre><matplotlib.axes._subplots.AxesSubplot at 0xab31ac8></pre>
</div>

<div class="cell border-box-sizing text_cell rendered"><div class="prompt input_prompt">
</div>
<div class="inner_cell">
<div class="text_cell_render border-box-sizing rendered_html">
<p>This seems promising.  Monday to Weds seems significantly better than Thurs and Friday.  Anyone care to hypothesize why?</p>
<p>I'll follow the same code pattern as with the "sell in May" analysis and group the days into these two halves, calculate in total as well as on a four-year-rolling basis.</p>
</div>
</div>
</div>
<div class="cell border-box-sizing code_cell rendered">
<div class="input">
<div class="prompt input_prompt">In [8]:</div>
<div class="inner_cell">
<div class="input_area">
<div class=" highlight hl-ipython3"><pre><span></span><span class="n">by_day</span><span class="p">[</span><span class="s1">'part_of_week'</span><span class="p">]</span> <span class="o">=</span> <span class="kc">None</span>
<span class="n">by_day</span><span class="o">.</span><span class="n">loc</span><span class="p">[</span><span class="n">by_day</span><span class="o">.</span><span class="n">day_of_week</span> <span class="o"><=</span><span class="mi">3</span><span class="p">,</span><span class="s1">'part_of_week'</span><span class="p">]</span> <span class="o">=</span> <span class="s1">'mon_weds'</span>
<span class="n">by_day</span><span class="o">.</span><span class="n">loc</span><span class="p">[</span><span class="n">by_day</span><span class="o">.</span><span class="n">day_of_week</span> <span class="o">></span><span class="mi">3</span><span class="p">,</span><span class="s1">'part_of_week'</span><span class="p">]</span> <span class="o">=</span> <span class="s1">'thu_fri'</span>

<span class="p">(</span><span class="n">by_day</span><span class="o">.</span><span class="n">groupby</span><span class="p">(</span><span class="s1">'part_of_week'</span><span class="p">)</span><span class="o">.</span><span class="n">pct_chg</span><span class="o">.</span><span class="n">mean</span><span class="p">()</span><span class="o">*</span><span class="mi">100</span><span class="p">)</span><span class="o">.</span><span class="n">plot</span><span class="o">.</span><span class="n">bar</span>\
<span class="p">(</span><span class="n">title</span><span class="o">=</span><span class="s1">'Avg Daily Log Return (%): </span><span class="se">\n</span><span class="s1">Mon-Wed vs Thu-Fri (1993-present)'</span>\
 <span class="p">,</span><span class="n">color</span><span class="o">=</span><span class="s1">'grey'</span><span class="p">)</span>

<span class="n">title</span><span class="o">=</span><span class="s1">'Avg Daily Log Return (%) by Part of Week</span><span class="se">\n</span><span class="s1">Four Year Moving Average (1993-present)'</span>
<span class="n">by_day</span><span class="p">[</span><span class="s1">'year'</span><span class="p">]</span> <span class="o">=</span> <span class="n">by_day</span><span class="o">.</span><span class="n">index</span><span class="o">.</span><span class="n">year</span>
<span class="n">ax</span> <span class="o">=</span> <span class="p">(</span><span class="n">by_day</span><span class="o">.</span><span class="n">groupby</span><span class="p">([</span><span class="s1">'year'</span><span class="p">,</span><span class="s1">'part_of_week'</span><span class="p">])</span><span class="o">.</span><span class="n">pct_chg</span><span class="o">.</span><span class="n">mean</span><span class="p">()</span><span class="o">.</span><span class="n">unstack</span><span class="p">()</span><span class="o">.</span><span class="n">rolling</span><span class="p">(</span><span class="mi">4</span><span class="p">)</span><span class="o">.</span><span class="n">mean</span><span class="p">()</span><span class="o">*</span><span class="mi">100</span><span class="p">)</span><span class="o">.</span><span class="n">plot</span><span class="p">()</span>
<span class="n">ax</span><span class="o">.</span><span class="n">axhline</span><span class="p">(</span><span class="n">y</span><span class="o">=</span><span class="mf">0.00</span><span class="p">,</span> <span class="n">color</span><span class="o">=</span><span class="s1">'grey'</span><span class="p">,</span> <span class="n">linestyle</span><span class="o">=</span><span class="s1">'--'</span><span class="p">,</span> <span class="n">lw</span><span class="o">=</span><span class="mi">2</span><span class="p">)</span>
<span class="n">ax</span><span class="o">.</span><span class="n">set_title</span><span class="p">(</span><span class="n">title</span><span class="p">)</span>
</pre></div>
</div>
</div>
</div>

<div class="cell border-box-sizing text_cell rendered"><div class="prompt input_prompt">
</div>
<div class="inner_cell">
<div class="text_cell_render border-box-sizing rendered_html">
<p>The average daily return (log) for Mon to Weds is considerably more than 2x the daily return of Thursdays and Fridays.</p>
<p>It also appears to be a good bit less stable than the "sell-in-May" results.   I'd be hesitant to say that the anomaly is dead, however.  Just periodically dormant.</p>
<h3 id="Day-of-Month">Day of Month<a class="anchor-link" href="#Day-of-Month">¶</a></h3><p>Now let's look in the data for any patters in the day of month:</p>
</div>
</div>
</div>
<div class="cell border-box-sizing code_cell rendered">
<div class="input">
<div class="prompt input_prompt">In [9]:</div>
<div class="inner_cell">
<div class="input_area">
<div class=" highlight hl-ipython3"><pre><span></span><span class="n">by_day</span><span class="p">[</span><span class="s1">'day_of_month'</span><span class="p">]</span> <span class="o">=</span> <span class="n">by_day</span><span class="o">.</span><span class="n">index</span><span class="o">.</span><span class="n">day</span> 

<span class="n">title</span><span class="o">=</span><span class="s1">'Avg Daily Log Return (%): by Day of Month (1993-present)'</span>

<span class="n">ax</span> <span class="o">=</span> <span class="p">(</span><span class="n">by_day</span><span class="o">.</span><span class="n">groupby</span><span class="p">(</span><span class="s1">'day_of_month'</span><span class="p">)</span><span class="o">.</span><span class="n">pct_chg</span><span class="o">.</span><span class="n">mean</span><span class="p">()</span><span class="o">*</span><span class="mi">100</span><span class="p">)</span><span class="o">.</span><span class="n">plot</span><span class="p">(</span><span class="n">xlim</span><span class="o">=</span><span class="p">(</span><span class="mi">1</span><span class="p">,</span><span class="mi">31</span><span class="p">),</span><span class="n">title</span><span class="o">=</span><span class="n">title</span><span class="p">)</span>
<span class="n">ax</span><span class="o">.</span><span class="n">axhline</span><span class="p">(</span><span class="n">y</span><span class="o">=</span><span class="mf">0.00</span><span class="p">,</span> <span class="n">color</span><span class="o">=</span><span class="s1">'grey'</span><span class="p">,</span> <span class="n">linestyle</span><span class="o">=</span><span class="s1">'--'</span><span class="p">,</span> <span class="n">lw</span><span class="o">=</span><span class="mi">2</span><span class="p">)</span>
</pre></div>
</div>
</div>
</div>

<div class="cell border-box-sizing text_cell rendered"><div class="prompt input_prompt">
</div>
<div class="inner_cell">
<div class="text_cell_render border-box-sizing rendered_html">
<p>It seems pretty clear that there are some parts of the month which, on average, have much better/worse returns.  By my eye, it appears that the change of month (from about the 28th to the 5th) as well as the early/mid-part of month (say 11th thru 18th) are the "good" days and the rest are not.</p>
<p>I'll follow the same approach and group the data into the "good days" (28-5, 11-18) and the "other days":</p>
</div>
</div>
</div>
<div class="cell border-box-sizing code_cell rendered">
<div class="input">
<div class="prompt input_prompt">In [10]:</div>
<div class="inner_cell">
<div class="input_area">
<div class=" highlight hl-ipython3"><pre><span></span><span class="n">by_day</span><span class="p">[</span><span class="s1">'part_of_month'</span><span class="p">]</span> <span class="o">=</span> <span class="kc">None</span>
<span class="n">good_days</span> <span class="o">=</span> <span class="p">[</span><span class="mi">1</span><span class="p">,</span><span class="mi">2</span><span class="p">,</span><span class="mi">3</span><span class="p">,</span><span class="mi">4</span><span class="p">,</span><span class="mi">5</span><span class="p">,</span><span class="mi">11</span><span class="p">,</span><span class="mi">12</span><span class="p">,</span><span class="mi">13</span><span class="p">,</span><span class="mi">14</span><span class="p">,</span><span class="mi">15</span><span class="p">,</span><span class="mi">16</span><span class="p">,</span><span class="mi">17</span><span class="p">,</span><span class="mi">18</span><span class="p">,</span><span class="mi">28</span><span class="p">,</span><span class="mi">29</span><span class="p">,</span><span class="mi">30</span><span class="p">,</span><span class="mi">31</span><span class="p">]</span>
<span class="n">by_day</span><span class="o">.</span><span class="n">loc</span><span class="p">[</span><span class="n">by_day</span><span class="o">.</span><span class="n">day_of_month</span><span class="o">.</span><span class="n">isin</span><span class="p">(</span><span class="n">good_days</span><span class="p">),</span><span class="s1">'part_of_month'</span><span class="p">]</span> <span class="o">=</span> <span class="s1">'good_days'</span>
<span class="n">by_day</span><span class="o">.</span><span class="n">loc</span><span class="p">[</span><span class="o">~</span><span class="n">by_day</span><span class="o">.</span><span class="n">day_of_month</span><span class="o">.</span><span class="n">isin</span><span class="p">(</span><span class="n">good_days</span><span class="p">),</span><span class="s1">'part_of_month'</span><span class="p">]</span> <span class="o">=</span> <span class="s1">'other_days'</span>

<span class="p">(</span><span class="n">by_day</span><span class="o">.</span><span class="n">groupby</span><span class="p">(</span><span class="s1">'part_of_month'</span><span class="p">)</span><span class="o">.</span><span class="n">pct_chg</span><span class="o">.</span><span class="n">mean</span><span class="p">()</span><span class="o">*</span><span class="mi">100</span><span class="p">)</span><span class="o">.</span><span class="n">plot</span><span class="o">.</span><span class="n">bar</span>\
<span class="p">(</span><span class="n">title</span><span class="o">=</span><span class="s1">'Avg Daily Log Return (%): </span><span class="se">\n</span><span class="s1">Days 1-5, 11-18, 28-31 vs Others (1993-present)'</span>\
 <span class="p">,</span><span class="n">color</span><span class="o">=</span><span class="s1">'grey'</span><span class="p">)</span>

<span class="n">title</span><span class="o">=</span><span class="s1">'Avg Daily Log Return (%) by Part of Month</span><span class="se">\n</span><span class="s1">Four Year Moving Average (1993-present)'</span>
<span class="n">by_day</span><span class="p">[</span><span class="s1">'year'</span><span class="p">]</span> <span class="o">=</span> <span class="n">by_day</span><span class="o">.</span><span class="n">index</span><span class="o">.</span><span class="n">year</span>
<span class="n">ax</span> <span class="o">=</span> <span class="p">(</span><span class="n">by_day</span><span class="o">.</span><span class="n">groupby</span><span class="p">([</span><span class="s1">'year'</span><span class="p">,</span><span class="s1">'part_of_month'</span><span class="p">])</span><span class="o">.</span><span class="n">pct_chg</span><span class="o">.</span><span class="n">mean</span><span class="p">()</span><span class="o">.</span><span class="n">unstack</span><span class="p">()</span><span class="o">.</span><span class="n">rolling</span><span class="p">(</span><span class="mi">4</span><span class="p">)</span><span class="o">.</span><span class="n">mean</span><span class="p">()</span><span class="o">*</span><span class="mi">100</span><span class="p">)</span><span class="o">.</span><span class="n">plot</span><span class="p">(</span><span class="n">title</span><span class="o">=</span><span class="n">title</span><span class="p">)</span>
<span class="n">ax</span><span class="o">.</span><span class="n">axhline</span><span class="p">(</span><span class="n">y</span><span class="o">=</span><span class="mf">0.00</span><span class="p">,</span> <span class="n">color</span><span class="o">=</span><span class="s1">'grey'</span><span class="p">,</span> <span class="n">linestyle</span><span class="o">=</span><span class="s1">'--'</span><span class="p">,</span> <span class="n">lw</span><span class="o">=</span><span class="mi">2</span><span class="p">)</span>
</pre></div>
</div>
</div>
</div>

<div class="output">
<div class="output_area">

oGAX25NWjK4Lzrmy5fdo+9QhcS98nNTwmlQlVN+VGF2T8t+TlcBbJPnvSnUSOjCU9SgSkXrA34En
/fOGItLIrx8PlDjn5vmqpVZ+ewYwEK2OSkq+GmwE8K1z7l/lXhoHlPUsGgKMLbf9z74XTh/gF3+r
/B7QX0Sa+x4Y/f22pBSr6+KvR31/zFZAX2BenZxEjNXimlRlOtBFRPYWkUzgbH+MpBOrayIijXwN
BP53pz9J/LsSkaBbv8se6B1BIdrwswy4CLgW7UnwHfAAO0Zq7wUsQBuTPkBTyQI0QnsozQbmAg8D
aUGfWxTX5HD0Nn428LV/nAS0RBvfF/plC7+/AI+jd1bfUK53Flott8g/Lgz63BLhugC/989n+eVF
QZ9bHV6Ttv7/2Tq088YyoKl/7ST/f24xcEvQ5xb0NUF7aM3yj7nJfE0ifVhKDGOMMRUkdFWSMcaY
umeBwRhjTAUWUXytCgAAAY9JREFUGIwxxlRggcEYY0wFFhiMMcZUYIHBGGNMBRYYjAmAiKQFXQZj
qmKBwZhqiMjdZbn8/fN7ReQaEblRRKaLzvFwZ7nXx/hka3PLJ1wTkQ0icpeITAMOq+PTMCZiFhiM
qd4IfAoFn57lbGAF0AXNmdMD6CUiR/r9hzrN75UNXCMiLf32Ruh8IznOuc/r8gSMqYlEz65qTOCc
cz+IyGoROQRoA8xEJ3Tp79cBGqOB4lM0GJzmt2f57auBUjShmzEJzQKDMZF5FrgAzaczEjgWuN85
91T5nUSnmT0OOMw5t0lEPgYa+Je3OOdK66rAxtSWVSUZE5m30FnvDkUz074HDPW5/hGR9j4b8O7A
Gh8U9kenEjUmqdgdgzERcM4Vi8hHwFr/V//7ItIVmOInftkAnA9MBC4TkdloBuCpQZXZmNqy7KrG
RMA3OucBZzrnFgZdHmPiyaqSjKmGiHRD57GYbEHBpAK7YzDGGFOB3TEYY4ypwAKDMcaYCiwwGGOM
qcACgzHGmAosMBhjjKng/wE4CzTJW3U1DAAAAABJRU5ErkJggg==
"/>
</div>
</div>
</div>
</div>
</div>
<div class="cell border-box-sizing text_cell rendered"><div class="prompt input_prompt">
</div>
<div class="inner_cell">
<div class="text_cell_render border-box-sizing rendered_html">
<p>Systematic investing in the 90's and 00's must have been easy!  Even since the spread between the good days vs. the other days has narrowed, it is still quite significant.  The below table shows the past 5 years' returns.  It's not even close...</p>
<p>I'm quite interested in hypotheses for this anomaly in particular, since it's so persistent over time - and undeniably still in effect.  Possibilities:</p>
<ul>
<li>Institutional/Retail fund flows?  </li>
<li>Options/futures settlements?  </li>
<li>Window dressing?</li>
<li>Buybacks?  </li>
</ul>
</div>
</div>
</div>
<div class="cell border-box-sizing code_cell rendered">
<div class="input">
<div class="prompt input_prompt">In [11]:</div>
<div class="inner_cell">
<div class="input_area">
<div class=" highlight hl-ipython3"><pre><span></span><span class="nb">print</span><span class="p">(</span><span class="n">by_day</span><span class="o">.</span><span class="n">groupby</span><span class="p">([</span><span class="s1">'year'</span><span class="p">,</span><span class="s1">'part_of_month'</span><span class="p">])</span><span class="o">.</span><span class="n">pct_chg</span><span class="o">.</span><span class="n">mean</span><span class="p">()</span><span class="o">.</span><span class="n">unstack</span><span class="p">()</span><span class="o">.</span><span class="n">tail</span><span class="p">(</span><span class="mi">5</span><span class="p">)</span><span class="o">*</span><span class="mi">100</span><span class="p">)</span>
</pre></div>
</div>
</div>
</div>
<div class="output_wrapper">
<div class="output">
<div class="output_area">
<div class="prompt"></div>
<div class="output_subarea output_stream output_stdout output_text">
<pre>part_of_month  good_days  other_days
year                                
2014            0.080266    0.014217
2015            0.022733   -0.016077
2016            0.058032    0.029643
2017            0.098606    0.056520
2018            0.063430    0.012229
</pre>
</div>
</div>
</div>
</div>
</div>
<div class="cell border-box-sizing text_cell rendered"><div class="prompt input_prompt">
</div>
<div class="inner_cell">
<div class="text_cell_render border-box-sizing rendered_html">
<h2 id="Conclusion">Conclusion<a class="anchor-link" href="#Conclusion">¶</a></h2><p>As irrational as it may seem, there are some major seasonality effects remaining in even the most liquid markets.  Quite honestly, this is <strong>much</strong> more significant than I expected to find.  If any of my fellow skeptics want to replicate this on their own datasets, please message me with your results.</p>
<p>If the future looks anything like the past (insert standard disclaimer about past performance...) then rules of thumb might be:</p>
<ul>
<li>Sell on Labor Day and buy on Halloween - especially do this on election years!  This assumes that you've got a productive use for the cash!  </li>
<li>Do your buying at Friday's close, do your selling at Wednesday's close</li>
<li>Maximize your exposure at the end/beginning of months and during the early-middle part of the month, lighten up.</li>
<li>Remember that, in most of these anomalies, <em>total</em> return would decrease by only participating in part of the market since any positive return is better than sitting in cash.  Risk-adjusted returns would be significantly improved by only participating in the most favorable periods.  It's for each investor to decide what's important to them.  </li>
</ul>
<p>I had intended to extend this analysis to other asset classes, but will save that for a future post.  I'd like to expand this to small caps, rest-of-world developed/emerging, fixed income, growth, value, etc...</p>
<h3 id="One-last-thing...">One last thing...<a class="anchor-link" href="#One-last-thing...">¶</a></h3><p>If you've found this post useful, please follow <a href="https://twitter.com/data2alpha">@data2alpha</a> on twitter and forward to a friend or colleague who may also find this topic interesting.</p>
<p>Finally, take a minute to leave a comment below.  Share your thoughts on this post or to offer an idea for future posts.  Thanks for reading!</p>
</div>
</div>
</div>

entry.title: Stock Prediction with ML: Feature Selection
entry.summary: This is the third post in my tutorial series on applying machine learning to stock prediction. This post is going to delve into the mechanics of feature selection - a critical step towards improving model robustness. This will cover a systematic approach for choosing between the many variations of features you've created during the feature engineering stage.
entry.content:

}

}
.prompt {
  /* This needs to be wide enough for 3 digit prompt numbers: In[100]: */
  min-width: 14ex;
  /* This padding is tuned to match the padding on the CodeMirror editor. */
  padding: 0.4em;
  margin: 0px;
  font-family: monospace;
  text-align: right;
  /* This has to match that of the the CodeMirror class line-height below */
  line-height: 1.21429em;
  /* Don't highlight prompt number selection */
  -webkit-touch-callout: none;
  -webkit-user-select: none;
  -khtml-user-select: none;
  -moz-user-select: none;
  -ms-user-select: none;
  user-select: none;

  cursor: default;

@media (max-width: 540px) {

.CodeMirror {

<div class="cell border-box-sizing text_cell rendered"><div class="prompt input_prompt">
</div>
<div class="inner_cell">
<div class="text_cell_render border-box-sizing rendered_html">
<h3 id="Introduction">Introduction<a class="anchor-link" href="#Introduction">¶</a></h3><p>This is the third post in my series on transforming data into alpha.  If you haven't yet see the <a href="data_management.html">data management</a> and <a href="feature_engineering.html">guide to feature engineering</a>, please take a minute to read those first...</p>
<p>This post is going to delve into the mechanics of <em>feature selection</em> to help choose between the many variations of features created in the feature engineering stage.   If you'd like to replicate and experiment with the below code, <em>you can download the source notebook for this post by right-clicking on the below button and choosing "save link as"</em></p>
<p><a href="https://github.com/convergenceIM/alpha-scientist/blob/master/content/03_Feature_Selection.ipynb" style="text-align: center;"><img src="images/button_ipynb-notebook.png" title="download ipynb"/></a></p>
<p>By design, many of the features you've created will be very similar to each other (aka "collinear") because you've derived them from the same underlying dataset.  If we were to keep many highly collinear features in our dataset used to train models, it would likely cause the model to "learn" some very funky and dangerous patterns.  I will discuss this in greater depth in a future post.</p>
<p>The goal of feature selection is to reduce our <em>possible</em> features into <em>the best</em> set of features to learn from data.  This will lead to models which <em>generalize</em> better (i.e., work well on data they haven't seen).  They will also be much more interpretable.</p>
</div>
</div>
</div>
<div class="cell border-box-sizing text_cell rendered"><div class="prompt input_prompt">
</div>
<div class="inner_cell">
<div class="text_cell_render border-box-sizing rendered_html">
<h3 id="Philosophy">Philosophy<a class="anchor-link" href="#Philosophy">¶</a></h3><p>In feature selection, we strive to meet two goals:</p>
<ol>
<li><strong>Strength</strong>:  Choose the features with the strongest, most persistent relationships to the target outcome variable.  The reasons for this are obvious.</li>
<li><strong>Orthogonality</strong>:  Minimize the amount of overlap or collinearity in your selected features.  The importance of orthogonality (non-overlap) of features is much greater than you might guess.  </li>
</ol>
<p>I am biased towards making feature selection a relatively mechanical process.  The "art" should mainly be encapsulated within the prior step (feature engineering) and the subsequent step (modeling).</p>
<p>Feature selection should, in my view, follow a heuristic and can be encoded into an algorithm if desired.  For purposes of this tutorial, I'll keep things relatively manual.</p>
</div>
</div>
</div>
<div class="cell border-box-sizing text_cell rendered"><div class="prompt input_prompt">
</div>
<div class="inner_cell">
<div class="text_cell_render border-box-sizing rendered_html">
<h3 id="Preparing-the-data">Preparing the data<a class="anchor-link" href="#Preparing-the-data">¶</a></h3><p>Let's dive in.  I will begin by loading prices and creating <em>outcomes</em> <code>DataFrame</code> as done in the <a href="data_management.html">post on data management</a>.</p>
</div>
</div>
</div>
<div class="cell border-box-sizing code_cell rendered">
<div class="input">
<div class="prompt input_prompt">In [1]:</div>
<div class="inner_cell">
<div class="input_area">
<div class=" highlight hl-ipython3"><pre><span></span><span class="c1">## Replace this section of imports with your preferred</span>
<span class="c1">## data download/access interface.  This calls a </span>
<span class="c1">## proprietary set of methods (ie they won't work for you)</span>

<span class="kn">from</span> <span class="nn">IPython.core.display</span> <span class="k">import</span> <span class="n">Image</span>

<span class="kn">import</span> <span class="nn">numpy</span> <span class="k">as</span> <span class="nn">np</span>
<span class="kn">import</span> <span class="nn">pandas</span> <span class="k">as</span> <span class="nn">pd</span>
<span class="n">pd</span><span class="o">.</span><span class="n">core</span><span class="o">.</span><span class="n">common</span><span class="o">.</span><span class="n">is_list_like</span> <span class="o">=</span> <span class="n">pd</span><span class="o">.</span><span class="n">api</span><span class="o">.</span><span class="n">types</span><span class="o">.</span><span class="n">is_list_like</span> <span class="c1"># remove once updated pandas-datareader issue is fixed</span>
<span class="c1"># https://github.com/pydata/pandas-datareader/issues/534</span>
<span class="kn">import</span> <span class="nn">pandas_datareader.data</span> <span class="k">as</span> <span class="nn">web</span>
<span class="o">%</span><span class="k">matplotlib</span> inline


<span class="k">def</span> <span class="nf">get_symbols</span><span class="p">(</span><span class="n">symbols</span><span class="p">,</span><span class="n">data_source</span><span class="p">,</span> <span class="n">begin_date</span><span class="o">=</span><span class="kc">None</span><span class="p">,</span><span class="n">end_date</span><span class="o">=</span><span class="kc">None</span><span class="p">):</span>
    <span class="n">out</span> <span class="o">=</span> <span class="n">pd</span><span class="o">.</span><span class="n">DataFrame</span><span class="p">()</span>
    <span class="k">for</span> <span class="n">symbol</span> <span class="ow">in</span> <span class="n">symbols</span><span class="p">:</span>
        <span class="n">df</span> <span class="o">=</span> <span class="n">web</span><span class="o">.</span><span class="n">DataReader</span><span class="p">(</span><span class="n">symbol</span><span class="p">,</span> <span class="n">data_source</span><span class="p">,</span><span class="n">begin_date</span><span class="p">,</span> <span class="n">end_date</span><span class="p">)</span>\
        <span class="p">[[</span><span class="s1">'AdjOpen'</span><span class="p">,</span><span class="s1">'AdjHigh'</span><span class="p">,</span><span class="s1">'AdjLow'</span><span class="p">,</span><span class="s1">'AdjClose'</span><span class="p">,</span><span class="s1">'AdjVolume'</span><span class="p">]]</span><span class="o">.</span><span class="n">reset_index</span><span class="p">()</span>
        
        <span class="n">df</span><span class="o">.</span><span class="n">columns</span> <span class="o">=</span> <span class="p">[</span><span class="s1">'date'</span><span class="p">,</span><span class="s1">'open'</span><span class="p">,</span><span class="s1">'high'</span><span class="p">,</span><span class="s1">'low'</span><span class="p">,</span><span class="s1">'close'</span><span class="p">,</span><span class="s1">'volume'</span><span class="p">]</span> <span class="c1">#my convention: always lowercase</span>
        <span class="n">df</span><span class="p">[</span><span class="s1">'symbol'</span><span class="p">]</span> <span class="o">=</span> <span class="n">symbol</span> <span class="c1"># add a new column which contains the symbol so we can keep multiple symbols in the same dataframe</span>
        <span class="n">df</span> <span class="o">=</span> <span class="n">df</span><span class="o">.</span><span class="n">set_index</span><span class="p">([</span><span class="s1">'date'</span><span class="p">,</span><span class="s1">'symbol'</span><span class="p">])</span>
        <span class="n">out</span> <span class="o">=</span> <span class="n">pd</span><span class="o">.</span><span class="n">concat</span><span class="p">([</span><span class="n">out</span><span class="p">,</span><span class="n">df</span><span class="p">],</span><span class="n">axis</span><span class="o">=</span><span class="mi">0</span><span class="p">)</span> <span class="c1">#stacks on top of previously collected data</span>
    <span class="k">return</span> <span class="n">out</span><span class="o">.</span><span class="n">sort_index</span><span class="p">()</span>
        
<span class="n">prices</span> <span class="o">=</span> <span class="n">get_symbols</span><span class="p">([</span><span class="s1">'AAPL'</span><span class="p">,</span><span class="s1">'CSCO'</span><span class="p">,</span><span class="s1">'AMZN'</span><span class="p">,</span><span class="s1">'YHOO'</span><span class="p">,</span><span class="s1">'MSFT'</span><span class="p">],</span><span class="n">data_source</span><span class="o">=</span><span class="s1">'quandl'</span><span class="p">,</span><span class="n">begin_date</span><span class="o">=</span><span class="s1">'2012-01-01'</span><span class="p">,</span><span class="n">end_date</span><span class="o">=</span><span class="kc">None</span><span class="p">)</span>

<span class="nb">print</span><span class="p">(</span><span class="n">prices</span><span class="o">.</span><span class="n">sort_index</span><span class="p">()</span><span class="o">.</span><span class="n">tail</span><span class="p">())</span>
</pre></div>
</div>
</div>
</div>
<div class="output_wrapper">
<div class="output">
<div class="output_area">
<div class="prompt"></div>
<div class="output_subarea output_stream output_stdout output_text">
<pre>                      open      high      low    close      volume
date       symbol                                                 
2018-03-26 MSFT      90.61    94.000    90.40    93.78  55031149.0
2018-03-27 AAPL     173.68   175.150   166.92   168.34  38962839.0
           AMZN    1572.40  1575.960  1482.32  1497.05   6793279.0
           CSCO      44.49    44.520    42.24    42.68  30088447.0
           MSFT      94.94    95.139    88.51    89.47  53704562.0
</pre>
</div>
</div>
</div>
</div>
</div>
<div class="cell border-box-sizing code_cell rendered">
<div class="input">
<div class="prompt input_prompt">In [2]:</div>
<div class="inner_cell">
<div class="input_area">
<div class=" highlight hl-ipython3"><pre><span></span><span class="n">outcomes</span> <span class="o">=</span> <span class="n">pd</span><span class="o">.</span><span class="n">DataFrame</span><span class="p">(</span><span class="n">index</span><span class="o">=</span><span class="n">prices</span><span class="o">.</span><span class="n">index</span><span class="p">)</span>
<span class="c1"># next day's opening change</span>
<span class="n">outcomes</span><span class="p">[</span><span class="s1">'close_1'</span><span class="p">]</span> <span class="o">=</span> <span class="n">prices</span><span class="o">.</span><span class="n">groupby</span><span class="p">(</span><span class="n">level</span><span class="o">=</span><span class="s1">'symbol'</span><span class="p">)</span><span class="o">.</span><span class="n">close</span><span class="o">.</span><span class="n">pct_change</span><span class="p">(</span><span class="o">-</span><span class="mi">1</span><span class="p">)</span> <span class="c1"># next day's returns</span>
<span class="n">outcomes</span><span class="p">[</span><span class="s1">'close_5'</span><span class="p">]</span> <span class="o">=</span> <span class="n">prices</span><span class="o">.</span><span class="n">groupby</span><span class="p">(</span><span class="n">level</span><span class="o">=</span><span class="s1">'symbol'</span><span class="p">)</span><span class="o">.</span><span class="n">close</span><span class="o">.</span><span class="n">pct_change</span><span class="p">(</span><span class="o">-</span><span class="mi">5</span><span class="p">)</span> <span class="c1"># next week's returns</span>
<span class="n">outcomes</span><span class="p">[</span><span class="s1">'close_10'</span><span class="p">]</span> <span class="o">=</span> <span class="n">prices</span><span class="o">.</span><span class="n">groupby</span><span class="p">(</span><span class="n">level</span><span class="o">=</span><span class="s1">'symbol'</span><span class="p">)</span><span class="o">.</span><span class="n">close</span><span class="o">.</span><span class="n">pct_change</span><span class="p">(</span><span class="o">-</span><span class="mi">10</span><span class="p">)</span> <span class="c1"># next two weeks' returns</span>
<span class="n">outcomes</span><span class="p">[</span><span class="s1">'close_20'</span><span class="p">]</span> <span class="o">=</span> <span class="n">prices</span><span class="o">.</span><span class="n">groupby</span><span class="p">(</span><span class="n">level</span><span class="o">=</span><span class="s1">'symbol'</span><span class="p">)</span><span class="o">.</span><span class="n">close</span><span class="o">.</span><span class="n">pct_change</span><span class="p">(</span><span class="o">-</span><span class="mi">20</span><span class="p">)</span> <span class="c1"># next month's (approx) returns</span>

<span class="nb">print</span><span class="p">(</span><span class="n">outcomes</span><span class="o">.</span><span class="n">tail</span><span class="p">())</span>
</pre></div>
</div>
</div>
</div>
<div class="output_wrapper">
<div class="output">
<div class="output_area">
<div class="prompt"></div>
<div class="output_subarea output_stream output_stdout output_text">
<pre>                    close_1  close_5  close_10  close_20
date       symbol                                       
2018-03-26 MSFT    0.048173      NaN       NaN       NaN
2018-03-27 AAPL         NaN      NaN       NaN       NaN
           AMZN         NaN      NaN       NaN       NaN
           CSCO         NaN      NaN       NaN       NaN
           MSFT         NaN      NaN       NaN       NaN
</pre>
</div>
</div>
</div>
</div>
</div>
<div class="cell border-box-sizing text_cell rendered"><div class="prompt input_prompt">
</div>
<div class="inner_cell">
<div class="text_cell_render border-box-sizing rendered_html">
<p>However, unlike the prior tutorials, we're going to engineer some features which are constructed to contain a relationship to the outcomes along with quite a bit of random noise.  Clearly, this is not something we'd do in real usage but will help to demonstrate the concept more clearly.</p>
<p><img src="https://i.pinimg.com/736x/cf/27/e3/cf27e3d83d8159e6d950408c4e6a3eb4--statistics-humor-data.jpg" width="400"/></p>
<p>Assume we have a target variable called <code>outcome</code> which can be (partially) predicted with three factors, <code>factor_1</code>, <code>factor_2</code> and <code>factor_3</code>.  There's also an unpredictble noise component.</p>
<p>We'll use <code>numpy.random</code> to graft dummy values mapped onto the indices of real price data.</p>
</div>
</div>
</div>
<div class="cell border-box-sizing code_cell rendered">
<div class="input">
<div class="prompt input_prompt">In [3]:</div>
<div class="inner_cell">
<div class="input_area">
<div class=" highlight hl-ipython3"><pre><span></span><span class="n">num_obs</span> <span class="o">=</span> <span class="n">prices</span><span class="o">.</span><span class="n">close</span><span class="o">.</span><span class="n">count</span><span class="p">()</span>
<span class="n">factor_1</span> <span class="o">=</span> <span class="n">pd</span><span class="o">.</span><span class="n">Series</span><span class="p">(</span><span class="n">np</span><span class="o">.</span><span class="n">random</span><span class="o">.</span><span class="n">randn</span><span class="p">(</span><span class="n">num_obs</span><span class="p">),</span><span class="n">index</span><span class="o">=</span><span class="n">prices</span><span class="o">.</span><span class="n">index</span><span class="p">)</span>
<span class="n">factor_2</span> <span class="o">=</span> <span class="n">pd</span><span class="o">.</span><span class="n">Series</span><span class="p">(</span><span class="n">np</span><span class="o">.</span><span class="n">random</span><span class="o">.</span><span class="n">randn</span><span class="p">(</span><span class="n">num_obs</span><span class="p">),</span><span class="n">index</span><span class="o">=</span><span class="n">prices</span><span class="o">.</span><span class="n">index</span><span class="p">)</span>
<span class="n">factor_3</span> <span class="o">=</span> <span class="n">pd</span><span class="o">.</span><span class="n">Series</span><span class="p">(</span><span class="n">np</span><span class="o">.</span><span class="n">random</span><span class="o">.</span><span class="n">randn</span><span class="p">(</span><span class="n">num_obs</span><span class="p">),</span><span class="n">index</span><span class="o">=</span><span class="n">prices</span><span class="o">.</span><span class="n">index</span><span class="p">)</span>
<span class="n">outcome</span> <span class="o">=</span> <span class="mf">1.</span><span class="o">*</span><span class="n">factor_1</span> <span class="o">+</span> <span class="mf">2.</span><span class="o">*</span><span class="n">factor_2</span> <span class="o">+</span> <span class="mf">3.</span><span class="o">*</span><span class="n">factor_3</span> <span class="o">+</span> <span class="mf">5.</span><span class="o">*</span><span class="n">np</span><span class="o">.</span><span class="n">random</span><span class="o">.</span><span class="n">randn</span><span class="p">(</span><span class="n">num_obs</span><span class="p">)</span>
<span class="n">outcome</span><span class="o">.</span><span class="n">name</span> <span class="o">=</span> <span class="s1">'outcome'</span>
<span class="n">outcome</span><span class="o">.</span><span class="n">tail</span><span class="p">()</span>
</pre></div>
</div>
</div>
</div>
<div class="output_wrapper">
<div class="output">
<div class="output_area">
<div class="prompt output_prompt">Out[3]:</div>
<div class="output_text output_subarea output_execute_result">
<pre>date        symbol
2018-03-26  MSFT      1.619244
2018-03-27  AAPL      0.669392
            AMZN     -7.372092
            CSCO     -0.209091
            MSFT     -8.924626
Name: outcome, dtype: float64</pre>
</div>
</div>
</div>
</div>
</div>
<div class="cell border-box-sizing text_cell rendered"><div class="prompt input_prompt">
</div>
<div class="inner_cell">
<div class="text_cell_render border-box-sizing rendered_html">
<p>Now, we will engineer several variations on features which each contain some information about the three factors, plus a few which contain some interaction effects, and some which do not contain any useful data.</p>
<p>Note that we are, again, "cheating" here for illustration purposes.</p>
</div>
</div>
</div>
<div class="cell border-box-sizing code_cell rendered">
<div class="input">
<div class="prompt input_prompt">In [4]:</div>
<div class="inner_cell">
<div class="input_area">
<div class=" highlight hl-ipython3"><pre><span></span><span class="n">features</span> <span class="o">=</span> <span class="n">pd</span><span class="o">.</span><span class="n">DataFrame</span><span class="p">(</span><span class="n">index</span><span class="o">=</span><span class="n">outcome</span><span class="o">.</span><span class="n">index</span><span class="p">)</span>
<span class="n">features</span><span class="p">[</span><span class="s1">'f11'</span><span class="p">]</span> <span class="o">=</span> <span class="mf">0.2</span><span class="o">*</span><span class="n">factor_1</span> <span class="o">+</span> <span class="mf">0.8</span><span class="o">*</span><span class="n">np</span><span class="o">.</span><span class="n">random</span><span class="o">.</span><span class="n">randn</span><span class="p">(</span><span class="n">num_obs</span><span class="p">)</span>
<span class="n">features</span><span class="p">[</span><span class="s1">'f12'</span><span class="p">]</span> <span class="o">=</span> <span class="mf">0.4</span><span class="o">*</span><span class="n">factor_1</span> <span class="o">+</span> <span class="mf">0.6</span><span class="o">*</span><span class="n">np</span><span class="o">.</span><span class="n">random</span><span class="o">.</span><span class="n">randn</span><span class="p">(</span><span class="n">num_obs</span><span class="p">)</span>
<span class="n">features</span><span class="p">[</span><span class="s1">'f13'</span><span class="p">]</span> <span class="o">=</span> <span class="mf">0.6</span><span class="o">*</span><span class="n">factor_1</span> <span class="o">+</span> <span class="mf">0.4</span><span class="o">*</span><span class="n">np</span><span class="o">.</span><span class="n">random</span><span class="o">.</span><span class="n">randn</span><span class="p">(</span><span class="n">num_obs</span><span class="p">)</span>

<span class="n">features</span><span class="p">[</span><span class="s1">'f21'</span><span class="p">]</span> <span class="o">=</span> <span class="mf">0.2</span><span class="o">*</span><span class="n">factor_2</span> <span class="o">+</span> <span class="mf">0.8</span><span class="o">*</span><span class="n">np</span><span class="o">.</span><span class="n">random</span><span class="o">.</span><span class="n">randn</span><span class="p">(</span><span class="n">num_obs</span><span class="p">)</span>
<span class="n">features</span><span class="p">[</span><span class="s1">'f22'</span><span class="p">]</span> <span class="o">=</span> <span class="mf">0.4</span><span class="o">*</span><span class="n">factor_2</span> <span class="o">+</span> <span class="mf">0.8</span><span class="o">*</span><span class="n">np</span><span class="o">.</span><span class="n">random</span><span class="o">.</span><span class="n">randn</span><span class="p">(</span><span class="n">num_obs</span><span class="p">)</span>
<span class="n">features</span><span class="p">[</span><span class="s1">'f23'</span><span class="p">]</span> <span class="o">=</span> <span class="mf">0.6</span><span class="o">*</span><span class="n">factor_2</span> <span class="o">+</span> <span class="mf">0.4</span><span class="o">*</span><span class="n">np</span><span class="o">.</span><span class="n">random</span><span class="o">.</span><span class="n">randn</span><span class="p">(</span><span class="n">num_obs</span><span class="p">)</span>

<span class="n">features</span><span class="p">[</span><span class="s1">'f31'</span><span class="p">]</span> <span class="o">=</span> <span class="mf">0.2</span><span class="o">*</span><span class="n">factor_3</span> <span class="o">+</span> <span class="mf">0.8</span><span class="o">*</span><span class="n">np</span><span class="o">.</span><span class="n">random</span><span class="o">.</span><span class="n">randn</span><span class="p">(</span><span class="n">num_obs</span><span class="p">)</span>
<span class="n">features</span><span class="p">[</span><span class="s1">'f32'</span><span class="p">]</span> <span class="o">=</span> <span class="mf">0.4</span><span class="o">*</span><span class="n">factor_3</span> <span class="o">+</span> <span class="mf">0.6</span><span class="o">*</span><span class="n">np</span><span class="o">.</span><span class="n">random</span><span class="o">.</span><span class="n">randn</span><span class="p">(</span><span class="n">num_obs</span><span class="p">)</span>
<span class="n">features</span><span class="p">[</span><span class="s1">'f33'</span><span class="p">]</span> <span class="o">=</span> <span class="mf">0.6</span><span class="o">*</span><span class="n">factor_3</span> <span class="o">+</span> <span class="mf">0.4</span><span class="o">*</span><span class="n">np</span><span class="o">.</span><span class="n">random</span><span class="o">.</span><span class="n">randn</span><span class="p">(</span><span class="n">num_obs</span><span class="p">)</span>

<span class="n">features</span><span class="p">[</span><span class="s1">'f41'</span><span class="p">]</span> <span class="o">=</span> <span class="mf">0.2</span><span class="o">*</span><span class="n">factor_1</span><span class="o">+</span><span class="mf">0.2</span><span class="o">*</span><span class="n">factor_2</span> <span class="o">+</span> <span class="mf">0.6</span><span class="o">*</span><span class="n">np</span><span class="o">.</span><span class="n">random</span><span class="o">.</span><span class="n">randn</span><span class="p">(</span><span class="n">num_obs</span><span class="p">)</span>
<span class="n">features</span><span class="p">[</span><span class="s1">'f42'</span><span class="p">]</span> <span class="o">=</span> <span class="mf">0.2</span><span class="o">*</span><span class="n">factor_2</span><span class="o">+</span><span class="mf">0.2</span><span class="o">*</span><span class="n">factor_3</span> <span class="o">+</span> <span class="mf">0.6</span><span class="o">*</span><span class="n">np</span><span class="o">.</span><span class="n">random</span><span class="o">.</span><span class="n">randn</span><span class="p">(</span><span class="n">num_obs</span><span class="p">)</span>
<span class="n">features</span><span class="p">[</span><span class="s1">'f43'</span><span class="p">]</span> <span class="o">=</span> <span class="mf">0.2</span><span class="o">*</span><span class="n">factor_3</span><span class="o">+</span><span class="mf">0.2</span><span class="o">*</span><span class="n">factor_1</span> <span class="o">+</span> <span class="mf">0.6</span><span class="o">*</span><span class="n">np</span><span class="o">.</span><span class="n">random</span><span class="o">.</span><span class="n">randn</span><span class="p">(</span><span class="n">num_obs</span><span class="p">)</span>

<span class="n">features</span><span class="p">[</span><span class="s1">'f51'</span><span class="p">]</span> <span class="o">=</span> <span class="n">np</span><span class="o">.</span><span class="n">random</span><span class="o">.</span><span class="n">randn</span><span class="p">(</span><span class="n">num_obs</span><span class="p">)</span>
<span class="n">features</span><span class="p">[</span><span class="s1">'f52'</span><span class="p">]</span> <span class="o">=</span> <span class="n">np</span><span class="o">.</span><span class="n">random</span><span class="o">.</span><span class="n">randn</span><span class="p">(</span><span class="n">num_obs</span><span class="p">)</span>
<span class="n">features</span><span class="p">[</span><span class="s1">'f53'</span><span class="p">]</span> <span class="o">=</span> <span class="n">np</span><span class="o">.</span><span class="n">random</span><span class="o">.</span><span class="n">randn</span><span class="p">(</span><span class="n">num_obs</span><span class="p">)</span>

<span class="nb">print</span><span class="p">(</span><span class="n">features</span><span class="o">.</span><span class="n">tail</span><span class="p">())</span>
</pre></div>
</div>
</div>
</div>
<div class="output_wrapper">
<div class="output">
<div class="output_area">
<div class="prompt"></div>
<div class="output_subarea output_stream output_stdout output_text">

</div>
</div>
</div>
</div>
<div class="cell border-box-sizing text_cell rendered"><div class="prompt input_prompt">
</div>
<div class="inner_cell">
<div class="text_cell_render border-box-sizing rendered_html">
<p>Before evaluating the features for predictive strength and orthogonality, we'll do a quick data preparation stage. It is sometimes vital to "standardize" or "normalize" data so that we get fair comparisons between features of differing scale.  Strictly speaking, since all of the doctored outcome and feature data is already drawn from normal distribution (using the numpy function <code>random.rnorm()</code>) we don't really need this step, but good practice to include.</p>
<p>Here, I'll use the scikit-learn <code>StandardScaler()</code> method and some pandas magic to transform the data.</p>
</div>
</div>
</div>
<div class="cell border-box-sizing code_cell rendered">
<div class="input">
<div class="prompt input_prompt">In [5]:</div>
<div class="inner_cell">
<div class="input_area">
<div class=" highlight hl-ipython3"><pre><span></span><span class="kn">import</span> <span class="nn">seaborn</span> <span class="k">as</span> <span class="nn">sns</span>

<span class="kn">import</span> <span class="nn">matplotlib.pyplot</span> <span class="k">as</span> <span class="nn">plt</span>
<span class="o">%</span><span class="k">matplotlib</span> inline
<span class="kn">from</span> <span class="nn">IPython.display</span> <span class="k">import</span> <span class="n">display</span>

<span class="kn">from</span> <span class="nn">scipy.cluster</span> <span class="k">import</span> <span class="n">hierarchy</span>
<span class="kn">from</span> <span class="nn">scipy.spatial</span> <span class="k">import</span> <span class="n">distance</span>

<span class="kn">from</span> <span class="nn">sklearn.preprocessing</span> <span class="k">import</span> <span class="n">StandardScaler</span><span class="p">,</span><span class="n">Normalizer</span>


<span class="c1">#f = features.dropna() #optional - to compare apples to apples</span>

<span class="c1"># standardize or normalize data </span>
<span class="n">std_scaler</span> <span class="o">=</span> <span class="n">StandardScaler</span><span class="p">()</span>
<span class="n">features_scaled</span> <span class="o">=</span> <span class="n">std_scaler</span><span class="o">.</span><span class="n">fit_transform</span><span class="p">(</span><span class="n">features</span><span class="o">.</span><span class="n">dropna</span><span class="p">())</span> 
<span class="nb">print</span> <span class="p">(</span><span class="n">features_scaled</span><span class="o">.</span><span class="n">shape</span><span class="p">)</span>
<span class="n">df</span> <span class="o">=</span> <span class="n">pd</span><span class="o">.</span><span class="n">DataFrame</span><span class="p">(</span><span class="n">features_scaled</span><span class="p">,</span><span class="n">index</span><span class="o">=</span><span class="n">features</span><span class="o">.</span><span class="n">dropna</span><span class="p">()</span><span class="o">.</span><span class="n">index</span><span class="p">)</span>
<span class="n">df</span><span class="o">.</span><span class="n">columns</span> <span class="o">=</span> <span class="n">features</span><span class="o">.</span><span class="n">dropna</span><span class="p">()</span><span class="o">.</span><span class="n">columns</span>
<span class="n">df</span><span class="o">.</span><span class="n">tail</span><span class="p">()</span>

<span class="c1"># standardize outcome as well </span>
<span class="n">outcome_df</span> <span class="o">=</span> <span class="n">outcome</span><span class="o">.</span><span class="n">to_frame</span><span class="p">()</span>
<span class="n">outcome_scaled</span> <span class="o">=</span> <span class="n">std_scaler</span><span class="o">.</span><span class="n">fit_transform</span><span class="p">(</span><span class="n">outcome_df</span><span class="o">.</span><span class="n">dropna</span><span class="p">())</span> 
<span class="n">outcome_scaled</span> <span class="o">=</span> <span class="n">pd</span><span class="o">.</span><span class="n">DataFrame</span><span class="p">(</span><span class="n">outcome_scaled</span><span class="p">,</span><span class="n">index</span><span class="o">=</span><span class="n">outcome_df</span><span class="o">.</span><span class="n">dropna</span><span class="p">()</span><span class="o">.</span><span class="n">index</span><span class="p">)</span>
<span class="n">outcome_scaled</span><span class="o">.</span><span class="n">columns</span> <span class="o">=</span> <span class="n">outcome_df</span><span class="o">.</span><span class="n">columns</span>
<span class="nb">print</span><span class="p">(</span><span class="n">outcome_scaled</span><span class="o">.</span><span class="n">tail</span><span class="p">())</span>
</pre></div>
</div>
</div>
</div>

<div class="output">
<div class="output_area">

</div>
</div>
</div>
</div>
</div>
<div class="cell border-box-sizing code_cell rendered">
<div class="input">
<div class="prompt input_prompt">In [6]:</div>
<div class="inner_cell">
<div class="input_area">
<div class=" highlight hl-ipython3"><pre><span></span><span class="n">corr</span> <span class="o">=</span> <span class="n">df</span><span class="o">.</span><span class="n">corrwith</span><span class="p">(</span><span class="n">outcome</span><span class="p">)</span>
<span class="n">corr</span><span class="o">.</span><span class="n">sort_values</span><span class="p">()</span><span class="o">.</span><span class="n">plot</span><span class="o">.</span><span class="n">barh</span><span class="p">(</span><span class="n">color</span> <span class="o">=</span> <span class="s1">'blue'</span><span class="p">,</span><span class="n">title</span> <span class="o">=</span> <span class="s1">'Strength of Correlation'</span><span class="p">)</span>
</pre></div>
</div>
</div>
</div>
